meanings.definition: A loose-fitting garment worn in ancient Rome.
meanings.sent1: In the play, the actor wore a tunica to portray a Roman citizen.
meanings.sent2: The tunica was made of light fabric to keep the wearer cool in the hot weather.
meanings.sent3: During the costume party, Sarah's tunica got tangled with her friend's toga.
meanings.sent4: The tunica of history wraps around us, connecting us to the past.
meanings.sent5: The tunica fluttered in the wind as the Roman soldier marched forward.

meanings.definition: The outermost layer of a plant stem.
meanings.sent1: The tunica of the stem protects the inner layers from damage.
meanings.sent2: Gardeners often prune the tunica to encourage healthy growth.
meanings.sent3: The tunica of the plant stem acted as a shield against the harsh sunlight.
meanings.sent4: The tunica of the stem was like a sturdy armor, defending against pests.
meanings.sent5: The tunica's green hue brightened the garden on a sunny day.

meanings.definition: A layer of tissue surrounding an organ.
meanings.sent1: The tunica surrounding the heart provides protection and support.
meanings.sent2: Doctors carefully examined the tunica for any signs of inflammation.
meanings.sent3: The tunica of the organ seemed to have a personality of its own during the surgery.
meanings.sent4: The tunica shielded the organ like a guardian, ensuring its well-being.
meanings.sent5: The tunica's delicate nature reminded the surgeon of handling fragile glass.
